Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Detector Technology and Science Education in the Era of Gravitational Wave Astrophysics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This CAREER award funds research at Syracuse University to support Advanced LIGO's quest to observe the gravitational wave universe. The research will include monitoring Advanced LIGO's data quality and developing hardware for upgrading the detectors. Specifically supported are i) The design and development of adaptive mode-matching for Advanced LIGO's output mode cleaner, enabling the use of non-classical squeezed-vacuum in the detector to improve the observational range. ii) A search for rare detector artifacts and low-level environmental correlations, prone to diminish the scientific return from Advanced LIGO.

Einstein's general theory of relativity predicts that violent cosmic events, such as for example colliding neutron stars, lead to tiny distortions of space-time here on earth, measurable as minuscule fluctuations in the distance between suspended optical mirrors. The NSF-funded Advanced LIGO project intends to precisely measure these so-called gravitational waves. Advanced LIGO's sensitivity is limited by the quantization of light, but can be improved by using an additional non-classical light source. Such light sources are however extremely sensitive to optical losses. This award supports the development of adaptive elements in the beam path to guarantee that all the light coming from the interferometer can be detected. Additionally, environmental disturbances have the potential to mimic the tiny distance fluctuations due to gravitational waves. This award supports monitoring Advanced LIGO's data for such disturbances. The first direct observation of gravitational waves will be a scientific break-through echoed in the news media, providing an outreach opportunity. The award supports workshops for high school teachers to bring the excitement of new scientific discoveries in this brand-new field of astronomy to high school class rooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded research towards supporting and improving the Advanced LIGO gravitational-wave detectors. During the award period the detectors made their Nobel prize winning discovery of gravitational waves (gravitational wave event GW150914). Numerous discoveries in subsequent observation runs followed, including the first multi-messenger observation of two merging neutron stars (gravitational wave event GW170817). Activities under this award included: (i) The development and testing of a new scheme to optimize laser light coupling to LIGO's optical cavities using existing alignment sensors. (ii) The development and testing of seismically isolated wave front shape actuation stages for the next Advanced LIGO upgrade. (iii) The development of a solid-state, CMOS chip-based camera capable of recoding videos of the optical beat pattern on interferometer readout beams at frequencies between 9MHz and 100MHz. The camera is intended for detection of laser wave front deformations that degrade the gravitational-wave detector performance. (iv) Long-term on-site presence of Syracuse University students and research personnel at the LIGO Hanford Observatory, helping with preparations for the observation runs. (v) The conceptual planning of the next-generation of gravitational-wave detectors, intended as next step after Advanced LIGO. And (vi) Research experience for undergraduate students, as well as numerous outreach presentations on the discovery of gravitational waves to a wide variety of audiences, spanning from primary school students to alumni organizations. The work under this award led to numerous academic publications and two US patents, US10453971B2 and US20160356983A1. The award supported two postdoctoral researchers, several undergraduate students and a number of graduate students, four of which defended their Ph.D. thesis during the award period.
